reasoning: This comment explains the mistake made by the player as it describes an alternative, more common move and justifies the current move's purpose, which allows the development of the knight.

comment: A typical move in this position. White prepares to castle long and Pawn storm the black King. However, 7. Nh3-f2 is a better idea. Seirawan-Istratescu, 1994 continued 7. Nh3 e5 8. d5 Nh5?! 9. g4 Nf4 10. Nxf4 exf4 11. Bxf4 Ne5 12. Be2 f5 13. exf5 gxf5 14. O-O fxg4 15. fxg4 h5!? 16. Bxe5 Bxe5 17. Qd3! gave white a clear advantage according to Seirawan in his book, Winning Chess Brilliancies. However, GM Nunn had prepared a special treatment of this line.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake by suggesting an alternative and better move, referencing Seirawan-Istratescu's game from 1994, which demonstrates that Nh3-f2 could have been a superior choice for White, leading to a more favorable position.

comment: A mistake. The move is logically designed to prevent black's Knights from going to g4 after white plays the natural f4 to drive away black's Knight on e5. Few better moves spring to mind for white here. 9. Bd3 Nxd3 uncoordinates the white position. 9. Ne2? Nxc4 loses material. Watch how black immediately targets the weakened g3 square.
reasoning: The comment accurately identifies the mistake by explaining the consequences of the move, indicating an alternative play, and highlighting the strategic weakness exploited by black.

comment: This move invites the Pawn fork which sacrifices black material for no clear tactical advantage. After the natural 11... gxf5 12. f4 Ng6 13. g3 would make black's Knights harmless. White is nearly forced to fork the black pieces in order to develop his own pieces.
reasoning: The comment accurately identifies a significant tactical error in the move, highlighting the potential fork and material loss without a clear benefit.

comment: The point of this entire line of sacrifice is made with this move. The white King is stuck in the center. Castling Queenside would run into Bh6 immediately. White finds it difficult to develop his kingside pieces. Black has the initiative with the f-file battery. Therefore, white will find it hard to devise a defensive plan.
reasoning: The comment accurately highlights the weaknesses in white's position, such as the central King's vulnerability, the difficulties in kingside development, and the control of the f-file by black, thus explaining the potential mistake made by the player.

comment: White can only curse his fortune. White cannot remove black's Rook on f3 because 16. Nxf3 Nxf3+ 17. Kd1 Bf5 18. Bg3 (not 18. Bd3 Nd4! 19. Bxd4 Qf3+ 20. Qe2 Qxh1+ 21. Kc2 Qxa1 wins material) 18... Qe3! 19. Bf2 Qxe4 20. Qxe4 Bxe4 21. Bg2 Rf8 gives black a superior end game. The black Queen assumes a dominating position in the middle of the board planning Bc8-f5 and Ra8-f8.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as it highlights the inability to remove Black's Rook on f3, leading to a superior endgame for Black.
